title: Translate visualisation notebooks to R
body:
# Translate the OpenMR visualisation notebooks to R!

## Project Description
The main idea is to translate the visualisation notebooks that are part of the OpenMR visualisation workshops, which are currently in Python and Octave 🙂 .

### Specific goal
We aim to create a notebook that follows the same structure as the ones in [Python](https://github.com/OpenMRBenelux/openmr2021-dataviz-workshop-python/blob/main/code/python_viz.ipynb) and [Octave](https://github.com/OpenMRBenelux/openmr2021-dataviz-workshop-python/blob/main/code/01_octave_viz.ipynb) (Other links: [Binder](https://mybinder.org/v2/gh/OpenMRBenelux/openmr2021-dataviz-workshop-python/HEAD?filepath=.%2Fcode%2F) and [GitHub Repo](https://github.com/OpenMRBenelux/openmr2021-dataviz-workshop-python)).

## Skills required to participate
We're mainly searching for R enthusiasts! Are you one but do not have that much experience? No problem, we'll get there! 💪 .

## Communication
Join the Discord channel dedicated to this hackathon project in the OpenMR Virtual 2021 Discord space!

title: Do you need a matlab licence to create Rainclouds ?

labels.name: git - 1
labels.description: can commit and push to a repository

body:
# Do you need a Matlab licence to create Rainclouds ?

When creating the data visualization workshop for openMR 2021 we realized that the code to create raincloud plots existed for python, R and Matlab.

https://github.com/RainCloudPlots/RainCloudPlots

We want to see whether the matlab code can also be used with Octave and how much work would be needed to make it work.

This can be a nice project to join if you want to see how to run your matlab code "for free" (no licence needed) and discover how to make your Matlab code Octave-Friendly.

### Coding skills

Matlab / Octave: beginner

### software specific sills

None

### GIT / GITHUB skills required

If it turns out to be doable

GIT - 1  can commit and push to a repository

## Link to your GitHub repo

This might not need a repo on its own as we must first see if this is even feasible at all.

## Communication

There will a chat channel in the discord server of openMR 2021

title: Create demo + template repository to use datalad in a binder

labels.name: git - 2
labels.description: comfortable working with branches and can do a pull request on another repository

labels.name: no code
labels.description: no coding experience required for this project

body:
#  Datalad + Binder : create reproducible interactive demos to explore your data

## Project Description

While preparing the data viz workshop for openMR 2021 we had to figure out how to download an MRI dataset into a binder (a virtual machine running in the cloud) to create an online interactive demo to explore data.

This was done by using Datalad a software that allows you version control your data (in brief: Datalad is to data what Git is to code).

Both the binder team and datalad team seem interested to create an template / demo to show how to do that.

So if anyone is interested to help create that demo and learn a bit about Binder and Datallad along the way.

## Skills required to participate

What different types of people could contribute?

### Coding skills

- no coding sills required

### software specific sills

Datalad - beginner or less
Binder - beginner  or less
Jupyter book - beginner or less

### GIT / GITHUB skills required

GIT - 2  - comfortable working with branches and can do a pull request on another repository 

## Integration

This would provide an easy way for researchers and teachers to create Binder based demos that easily integrate data from all the datasets that datalad provides access to. 

## Preparation material

Might be good (but not necesary) to have a look at:

- the intro and chapter 1 of the datalad handbook: http://handbook.datalad.org/en/latest/
- the tutorials for Binder: https://mybinder.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tutorials/index.html

## Link to your GitHub repo

Not an official repo yet but most of the "hard" content is already in there. It "just" needs to be turned into a stand alone repository with documentation.

https://github.com/OpenMRBenelux/openmr2021-dataviz-workshop-python

## Communication

- datalad-binder channel in the Discord of openMR2021

title: ⚒  Exploring a BIDS-DID Specification for Research Participant Data Self-Sovereignty

labels.name: BIDS
labels.description: projects involves around or uses BIDS

body:
#  Exploring a BIDS-DID Specification for Research Participant Data Self-Sovereignty

## Project Description
The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) provides a high level of protection for health and genetic data (Article 9), the conditions for consent (Article 7), defines individual rights of data subjects (Articles 13-22), and describes mechanisms for data subjects to enforce their rights (Articles 77-84). 

The collection and banking of large datasets must be justified by the societal benefit and balanced against respect for dignity, autonomy, privacy, and confidentiality of individuals. Researchers must show that data cannot lead to "re-identifiability" and must describe procedures to protect users and allow them to opt-out of research projects that violate a person's ethical beliefs (discrimination, profiling, unethical weapons, marginalization). 

A decentralized identity (DID) can streamline scientific human subjects research by allowing users to grant/revoke access to data collected under their DID. The Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) provides clarity for data interoperability between research studies. However, the current specification leaves use-rights and licenses in the hands of the researchers/institutions sharing the data.

This project is an extension of a [previous hack-a-thon project](http://brainhack.org/global2020/project/project_95/) to build open-source toolkits for decentralized science (De-Sci).

### Specific goal
In this project, we will explore the feasibility of integrating existing DID frameworks with the BIDS specification to enable GDPR-compliant sharing of datasets. The milestones for this project are outlined below! 

- [ ] Summarize GDPR regulations relevant to collecting neuroimaging data from human subjects
- [ ] Outline a revision to the BIDS specification to include DID tagging of participant data
- [ ] Design a UI for uploading encrypted personal data to distributed cloud storage (IPFS)
- [ ] Implement Data Permissions Access/Revocation with 3box profiles API
- [ ] Demonstrate execution of a BIDS-app with confidential cloud computing on BIDS-DID dataset.

## Skills required to participate
The only requirement is an interest to learn more about GDPR in the age of Web 3.0, DID, federated learning, and confidential cloud computing!

### Coding skills
The latter goals will require at least a beginner level of the following:

| language          | level of expertise required   |
|-------------------|-------------------------------|
| python            | beginner |
| javascript        | beginner |
| unix command line | beginner |

### software specific sills

- no software specific skills required

### GIT / GITHUB skills required

| level   | description                                                                       |
|---------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| GIT - 0 | no prior git knowledge                                                            |
| GIT - 1 | can commit and push to a repository                                               |
| GIT - 2 | comfortable working with branches and can do a pull request on another repository |
| GIT - 3 | can work with continuous integration                                              |

## Integration
Our project is constructed to integrate with a variety of professional expertise or lay person interest! 

- A lawyer can summarize GDPR implications for neuroimaging and the pros/cons of DID. 
- An imager can describe data collection/storage challenges 
- An artist can create educational materials and graphics
- A web programmer can build a front-end for interacting with data

## Preparation material

[IDX: Identity protocol for Open Applications](https://developers.idx.xyz/learn/welcome/)
[IDX Specification](https://developers.idx.xyz/learn/overview/)
[3box Profiles Documentation](https://docs.3box.io/build/wallets)
[3box Storage Documentation](https://docs.3box.io/api/storage)
[Infura for IPFS Data Storage](https://infura.io/docs/ipfs/post/add)
[BIDS Specification](https://bids-specification.readthedocs.io/en/stable/01-introduction.html)
[GDPR and the research exemption](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41431-019-0386-5)

## Link to your GitHub repo
[DeSci Github Repo](https://github.com/opscientia/desci) 

## Communication
Join us on Discord

[![Opscientia](https://img.shields.io/discord/819266495972507699.svg?label=Discord&logo=Discord&colorB=7289da&style=for-the-badge)](https://discord.gg/S5ama56RPz)

title: fMRwhy: BIDS-compatible multi-echo fMRI analysis and quality control with SPM12/MATLAB/Octave

labels.name: BIDS
labels.description: projects involves around or uses BIDS

labels.name: git - 2
labels.description: comfortable working with branches and can do a pull request on another repository

body:
# `fMRwhy`: BIDS-compatible multi-echo fMRI analysis and quality control with SPM12/MATLAB/Octave

![fmrwhy](https://github.com/jsheunis/fMRwhy/raw/master/assets/fmrwhy_logo_2020.png)

## Project Description

With this hackathon I would like to onboard anyone who wants to join, contribute to, or learn more about the `fMRwhy` project: a toolbox for BIDS-compatible multi-echo fMRI analysis and data quality control with SPM12/MATLAB/Octave. 

You can access more information about the toolbox here:
- [Documentation](https://fmrwhy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/)
- [Code base](https://github.com/jsheunis/fMRwhy)
- [Twitter thread](https://twitter.com/fmrwhy/status/1362001858491998209?s=20)

If you go through the documentation and code base you will notice that many aspects are lacking, poorly implemented, undocumented, and more. That's why the project is at a great stage to receive contributions, from updates to the documentation to setting up a testing framework.

### Specific goal
During the weeks before the hackathon, I will create specific issues on the `fMRwhy` GitHub repo that will guide new contributors. These issues will likely relate to the following aspects that require improvement:
- Creating a more user-friendly README
- Testing the toolbox using your own or publicly available data
- Writing unit tests (currently, there are none 😬)
- Setting up a unit/integration testing framework
- Contributing to the documentation, including:
  - populating the section on multi-echo fMRI
  - populating the section on real-time fMRI
  - populating the API
- Adding docstrings to most functions
- Adding visualisation features to the fMRI QC report
- Creating tutorials for using toolbox features

## Skills required to participate
Anyone who wants to contribute should be able to contribute. There are, however, some required skills depending on the features that you'd like to contribute to:

- For logging issues or feature requests: a keen interest and familiarity with describing issues via GitHub
- For testing the toolbox: a basic understanding of fMRI analysis with SPM12/MATLAB and BIDS data
- For contributing to the documentation: git/github, sphinx, sphinx-contrib/matlabdomain, reStructuredText
- For contributing to the code: git/github, MATLAB, javascript, html, css
- For creating tutorials: git/github, using MATLAB/Octave with Jupyter Notebooks

**Specific levels of requirement for if you want to contribute to specific software features include:**

| language          | level of expertise required   |
|-------------------|-------------------------------|
| MATLAB            | beginner / confirmed / expert |
| javascript              | confirmed / expert |
| html              | confirmed / expert |
| css              | confirmed / expert |
| SPM        | beginner / confirmed / expert |
| GIT - 2 | comfortable working with branches and can do a pull request on another repository |

If you don't have the required skills but are keen to acquire them while contributing, please feel free to reach out!

## Integration
_How would your project integrate a physicist/imager/clinician/psychologist/computational scientist/maker/artist/lawyer as collaborator?_

_...to be determined..._

## Preparation material
- [Documentation for `fMRwhy`](https://fmrwhy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/)
- [Multi-echo fMRI overview](https://tedana.readthedocs.io/en/stable/multi-echo.html)
- [sphinxcontrib-matlabdomain](https://sphinxcontrib-matlabdomain.readthedocs.io/en/latest/)
- [Readthedocs](https://readthedocs.org/)
- [BIDS website](https://bids.neuroimaging.io/)
- [BIDS documentation](https://bids-specification.readthedocs.io/en/stable/)

## Link to your GitHub repo

[`fMRwhy` on GitHub](https://github.com/jsheunis/fMRwhy)

## Communication

[![Mattermost chat](https://img.shields.io/badge/chat-on%20mattermost-blue)](https://mattermost.brainhack.org/brainhack/channels/fmrwhy)
